subject: Re: How can I get Junit Test to run in parallel threads?
msgSnippet: Mike, I am very curious about your position. Do you expect renumeration from commercial vendors, or is it an issue of respect? I ve released several open

Mike,

I am very curious about your position. Do you expect renumeration 
from commercial vendors, or is it an issue of respect? I've released 
several open source products, none as cool as your :), and I am faced 
with the same dilemma.

Regards,
David

--- In junit@y..., Mike Clark <mike@c...> wrote:
> Dave Astels wrote:
> 
> >On Wed, 2002-10-02 at 16:25, Michael Silverstein wrote:
> >
> >    We have a product called 'Enhanced JUnit' (hence my interest 
in JUnit
> >    extensibility issues) that (among other things) will disburse 
JUnit tests
> >    across threads, VMs, and CPUs for concurrent execution.
> >
> >http://www.silvermark.com/Product/enhancedjunit/
> >
> >Not to start a flame war... but why don't you follow Beck&Gamma's
> >example and give it to the JUnit community as so many others have 
done
> >with their extensions?
> >  
> >
> 
> It's not my intent to add kindling, but this brings up a broader 
issue.
> 
> You may find it interesting that Enhanced JUnit distributes 
JUnitPerf. 
>  I sure did when I learned about it... when the product first hit 
the 
> streets.  
> 
> Now don't get me wrong, I'm all about free enterprise.  There's no 
doubt 
> Enhanced JUnit adds its own bells and whistles over and above the 
open 
> source goodies it includes.  Indeed, distributing tests across 
separate 
> VMs is unique.  But Dave's use of the word "community" above struck 
a 
> chord with me.  
> 
> As a member of this community, and the open source community in 
general, 
> it got me to thinking about the licenses I use for the stuff I 
build. 
>  Anything I craft in the future may just be licensed such that 
> commercial redistribution rights are only available by writing me. 
>  Non-commercial redistribution, and its use in the development of 
> non-commercial products, will be freely granted.  In other words, 
if I 
> contribute to this community in good faith, commercial vendors have 
to 
> ask before leveraging my wares.  
> 
> I guess I expected that type of communication would happen 
naturally 
> inside of a community.  It won't be the first time I've been naive, 
nor 
> the last.  Live and learn.
> 
> Mike
> 
> -- 
> Mike Clark
> Clarkware Consulting Inc.
> http://www.clarkware.com
